list-items.description: Coca-Cola’s executives have called 2015 a “transition year,” as the beverage giant makes moves to better position itself in a world where global volume for its beverages has been muted. But surprisingly, Coke kicked off the year with a bang: revenue grew 1% to $10.71 billion in the first quarter, the first increase in nine quarters. The namesake Coca-Cola brand, as well as Coke Zero, Sprite and Fanta all performed well, offsetting a decline for Diet Coke. Diet sodas have posted lagging volume, as consumers are more concerned about the health effects of artificial sweeteners.

videos.title: Muhtar Kent, CEO of The Coca-Cola Company, on diversity
videos.author: Fortune Video

twitter.description: Coca-Cola on the Fortune 500 via @FortuneMagazine

thumbnail.caption: An employee works on a production line at the Coca-Cola company's new $106 million plant in Shijiazhuang in north China's Hebei province.

seo.title: Coca-Cola (KO) Stock Price, Financials and News | Fortune 500

strengths: Coke has enviable name recognition for many of its brands, and extensive relationships with retailers whenever it wants to bring a new product to market. That will help it muscle onto store shelves when it wants to debut a new milk, like Coke's Fairlife, and another other beverage category it tinkers with.
Coke's name also got a big boost in the "Mad Men" season finale, which featured the company's iconic 1971 "Hilltop" ad.
weaknesses: While Coke is the world's largest beverage company it is also too highly exposed to that category. Rival Pepsi, for example, is almost a completely different company as it derives a lot of its business from the sale of snacks.
Diet Coke is one of the company's biggest sellers in the U.S., but it is hard to determine just how Coke can turn that brand's performance around in the face of such stiff headwinds.
opportunities: The company could also mull an acquisition of a hot startup beverage brand, or perhaps make another splashy launch in a beverage category it doesn't yet dominate.
Coke products will be featured in Keurig Green Mountain's upcoming at-home cold drink maker, called "Keurig Kold," which debuts this fall.
threats: Sales of carbonated soft drinks have slid for 10 straight years.
The industry has struggled as consumers turn to juices, flavored waters and other beverage options they deem healthier.

list-items.description: As conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan wound down, the world’s biggest defense contractor faced headwinds. Cuts in defense budget spending are a constant worry for Lockheed Martin, which makes the lion’s share of its sales from the U.S. Department of Defense. Nevertheless, the latest defense budget proposed by President Obama for 2016 keeps all major programs in place and spending on weapons acquisitions even increased a bit. Also, the Pentagon has decided to purchase nearly 20 additional F-35 Joint Strike Fighter jets. The Bethesda, Md.-based company’s stock has doubled over the past couple of years, helped by investments in areas like cybersecurity and rocketry. Plus, the world isn’t getting any less dangerous: good news for a defense and security company.

list-items.description: The big new for FedEx this year is the company’s plan to acquire Dutch delivery firm TNT Express in a $4.8 billion deal. The all-cash deal, announced in April, would help expand FedEx’s presence in Europe, where it competes with UPS and DHL Express of Germany. A possible FedEx-TNT merger comes a couple of years after European regulators blocked a bid for TNT by UPS over antitrust concerns.

twitter.description: FedEx on the Fortune 500 via @FortuneMagazine

thumbnail.caption: Fedex envelopes.
thumbnail.credit: Photograph by Sam Kaplan; Styling by Lauren Shields for Fortune

seo.title: FedEx (FDX) Stock Price, Financials and News | Fortune 500

strengths: While growth of global trade has slowed, companies of all sizes depend on FedEx and other shipping companies for the delivery of just-in-time inventory to help them compete.
E-commerce spending continues to rise as spending at brick-and-mortar stores either slows or declines, resulting in more business for companies like FedEx.
weaknesses: Challenging global economic conditions can result in a poor performance. Less emphasis on priority shipments can hurt the company's profitability. In 2014, about 3,600 employees left FedEx as a result of a voluntary buyout program.
Streamlining efforts can also result in some uncertainty as an organization attempts to get leaner.
opportunities: FedEx, meanwhile, would help strengthen TNT with investments and global scope.

The TNT Express deal is the most obvious opportunity. It would combine TNT's strong European road platform and hub in Belgium with FedEx's strength in other regions globally, including North America and Asia.
threats: Package companies always face a threat from a global economic slowdown.

Mergers, while always promising on paper, also come with a period of uncertainty as it takes time to combine two corporate cultures, determine what areas of overlap can be axed, and also develop clear goals as a combined company.

list-items.description: The U.S. shale boom and overall oil production increases helped Plains nearly quadruple profits two years in a row. However, Plains—a holding company for Plains All American Pipeline—is bracing for the industry production slowdown, brought on by last year’s oil price crash. Plains CEO Greg Armstrong downwardly revised the company’s expected earnings and spending for 2015, though Plains still plans to expand its pipeline infrastructure in the Permian and Delaware basins, as well as in other regions.

Operations include petroleum refining and pipelines; the supply, marketing and distribution of refined fuels; and the blending, sale and distribution of lubricants, among other businesses. Its origins date back to the early 1930s.
weaknesses: The company's revenues are affected by market prices for commodities such as crude oil, natural gas, fertilizer and grain.
Commodity prices are affected by a wide range of factors beyond CHS's control, including weather, drought, and insect damage.
opportunities: The company has said one of its core strategic initiatives includes global expansion.
CHS only generates about 10% of net sales outside of the U.S.
threats: The CHS's energy segment derives its revenue through refining, wholesaling and retailing of petroleum products.
As such, profitability for that business largely leans on the margin between the cost of crude oil that CHS refines and the selling price it can obtain for its refined products.

list-items.description: After its acquisition of US Airways in 2013, American Airlines became the world’s largest airline. By the end of the year, the former brand will be absorbed completely. Taking on a new fleet is no simple task. The airline will have to merge its computer systems—such as those used for bookings and reservations—which could cause upsets. The Fort Worth, Texas-based company has been benefiting, as has its peers, from the low cost of oil as well as increased travel abroad for U.S. residents thanks to a strong dollar. According to the company on a recent earnings call, however, demand in the Latin American markets has “softness.”

list-items.description: The pharma company’s revenues have slipped in recent years due to patent expirations, but Merck, whose diabetes drugs and Measles vaccine did well in 2014, freshened up its aging portfolio with a handful of newly approved drugs. The drugmaker has narrowed its focus to a few key therapeutic areas and is chucking the rest–notably, its OTC business, which it sold to Bayer for $14.2 billion last May. The company has since acquired the biotech Idenix, to bulk up its efforts in Hepatitis C, and Cubist Pharmaceuticals, a company developing antibiotics against superbugs. But it’s Merck’s bet on immuno-oncology meds—promising and pricey treatment for a range of cancers—that has investors most excited.

list-items.description: Home is where the heart, and profit is, so the Minnesota-based electronics retailer is exiting China and has pared its Canadian business to focus on its fragile U.S. comeback. Best Buy enjoyed a surprisingly strong 2014 holiday season, helped by popular home-theater systems and smart phones. After years of serving as a showroom by customers who then go on Amazon, Best Buy has been fighting back, strengthening its e-commerce and using more floor space for shop-in-shops for leading brands. But the company still has to navigate tough waters: it has warned investors that weak demand for many consumer electronics and declining prices will weigh on sales for the first half of 2015. And its Geek Squad services business is struggling. Still, CEO Hubert Joly has so far done the impossible since taking the reins in 2012: keeping his company in the game long after many observers have written it off

list-items.description: Under the leadership of CEO Richard Anderson, the airline has placed a number of unusual bets, including buying half a stake in Virgin Atlantic and purchasing its own oil refinery in 2012. That latter deal–intended to save the Atlanta-based company money on fuel bills–may seem like a folly after the cost of oil dropped precipitously last year. Nevertheless, the company remains committed to its supply chain “vertical integration.” Relying mainly on refurbished older airplanes, it remains to be seen whether this strategy to lessen capital expenses will pose a risk moving forward. In the meantime, the airline this year launched a restructured frequent flier program to help court business travelers, and it has been investing heavily in a terminal at the John F. Kennedy airport in New York where it sees opportunities to grow.

list-items.description: The Morristown, N.J.-based conglomerate, which manufacturers everything from drone engines to security systems to its signature home thermostats, has been on a tear, quadrupling its market capitalization to $80 billion since CEO David Cote took over in 2002. The company has demonstrated strong growth during his tenure, doubling its revenue to $40 billion in that time. Recently inked deals—an agreement in April to outfit the cockpits of a future Southwest Airlines’ Boeing fleet with avionics and another in May to support a Nigerian oil refinery alongside the West African industrial powerhouse the Dangote Group—promise to keep its business on track. But analysts think it’s about time the cash-rich company made a major acquisition to keep that growth fueled.

list-items.description: HCA Holdings, the biggest for-profit hospital operator with 168 hospitals and 113 free-standing surgery centers, has been cashing in as more patients with insurance walk through its hospital doors as a result of the Affordable Care Act. For four quarters running, the Nashville-based company has unveiled an upbeat preview of its quarterly report. In the first three months of 2015, earnings rose 70% as admissions continued to improve. HCA also said it would increase its three-year capital spending plan by $500 million to a total of roughly $7.7 billion “to meet growing capital investment opportunities” across its existing markets. There is one grey cloud on the horizon which could slow HCA’s plans. The Supreme Court will rule on the legality of the ACA’s insurance subsidies this year, which if they are struck down will cut into HCA’s bottom line.

twitter.description: HCA Holdings on the Fortune 500 via @FortuneMagazine

list-items.description: Post-financial crisis regulations hit Goldman Sach’s businesses harder than other banks. But the Wall Street firm has adapted. In the past year profits have come roaring back. The firms’ return on equity, a key profit metric for financial firms, recently neared 13%, more than double what it was a few years ago, but still far below the 20% it used to be before the financial crisis. Nonetheless, investors still see Goldman as too complex, and its shares have lagged rivals. The firm still needs to either scale back or exit some of its businesses, as more post-financial crisis regulations go into effect.

weaknesses: Goldman still generates a large portion of its profits from such businesses as private equity and trading, which the firm is likely to be forced to exit or scale back due to new regulations.
It has stumbled on the Federal Reserve's stress tests in the past.
opportunities: It's trying to build its wealth management business, which could make earnings less volatile.
Goldman has been using its ties to corporations and investors to do more commercial lending, particularly in real estate, where it is still a very small player.
threats: Bigger rivals JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America have muscled their way into investment banking.
A drop in stocks or bonds could hurt earnings, as Goldman is more exposed to the markets than other large banks.

list-items.description: Cloud is now king for enterprise giant Oracle. The technology company established its dominance as a provider of software and databases for enterprise data centers. Last year, Oracle surpassed IBM to become the world’s second-largest software vendor by pulling in US $29.6 billion in software sales in 2013. But as more and more companies are using the cloud to power computing software and applications, Oracle is now shifting its software strategy and will make all of its software available to download in a subscription model from the internet come this fall. There’s a good reason for his move: revenue from the company’s cloud software products rose 29% in Oracle’s Q3 earnings earlier this year. And according to the company, Oracle is on track to sell more than $1 billion of new cloud subscriptions this fiscal year.

strengths: Restructured its sales force and compensation three years ago to focus on selling cloud software
Cloud software business is growing
weaknesses: Cloud-based software business is filled with worthy competitors including Workday, Salesforce, Microsoft and others.
opportunities: Instead of building subscription software in house, the company could acquire growing cloud software providers. Oracle has spent more than $50 billion to acquire 90 to 100 companies in the past ten years.
threats: Oracle is behind Amazon Web Services and Microsoft in offering cloud services, AWS, in particular, has the majority market share.

list-items.description: Morgan Stanley CEO James Gorman has won plaudits for shifting the bank away from Wall Street’s riskiest businesses. But it hasn’t paid off for the bank’s bottom line. Morgan Stanley’s return on equity, a key measure for financial firm’s profitability, fell in 2014 to just over 4%, about a quarter of many of its rivals. For now, shareholders, though, have rewarded the company for its flight to safety.

twitter.description: Morgan Stanley on the Fortune 500 via @FortuneMagazine

thumbnail.caption: The Morgan Stanley headquarters in New York.

seo.title: Morgan Stanley (MS) Stock Price, Financials and News | Fortune 500

strengths: Morgan Stanley has a very big asset management division, which produces low-risk, consistent revenue.
Has a very strong investment banking relationship with technology companies.
weaknesses: Profit ratios are much lower than rivals.
Morgan Stanley has relatively few deposits and a lower credit rating than rivals, which lowers its access to financing and could potentially hurt its trading businesses.
opportunities: Morgan Stanley is using its ties to corporations and investors to do more commercial lending, particularly in commercial real estate, which it is a small player.
threats: Profits in Morgan Stanley's large retail brokerage division tend to be tied to the stock market, which is at all time highs. If stocks were to fall, individuals would likely be less interested in investing in stocks.

list-items.description: The meats producer last year won a food fight to earn the right to buy Hillshire Brands, scooping the asset away from rival Pilgrim’s Pride. The deal allowed Tyson to combine its stock of chicken, beef and pork with Hillshire’s well-known brands and private label products, including Hillshire Farm, Jimmy Dean sausages and Ball Park meats. The deal also gave Tyson more exposure to the breakfast occasion, where previously it had little presence.

twitter.description: Tyson Foods on the Fortune 500 via @FortuneMagazine

thumbnail.caption: Packages of Tyson brand chicken in the meat department of a supermarket in the New York.

seo.title: Tyson Foods (TSN) Stock Price, Financials and News | Fortune 500

strengths: Food analysts say that U.S. consumers want more protein in their diet, believing that meats, fish and other protein-rich foods can help contribute to a healthier diet.
That trend should help Tyson Foods, which produces chicken, beef and pork.
weaknesses: High exposure to commodities. For example, corn, soybean meal and other feed ingredients account for roughly 68% of the cost to grow a live chicken.

Production and pricing of those commodities can constantly change and Tyson Foods has limited or no control over how those markets move. Outbreaks and disease can also occur outside the company's control.
opportunities: Synergies include the combination of sales and marketing teams, as well as supply chain resources.
The Hillshire Brands deal is a true opportunity. There are millions that can be saved as Tyson completes its integration plans.
threats: While companies love to tout deals, mergers can also be a risk. Tyson's integration efforts could take longer to process or may not be as successful as it hopes.
Streamlining supply chains, cutting overhead costs and eliminating overlapping operations takes time and Tyson could make some missteps along the way.

list-items.description: Grocery operator Safeway was bought earlier this year by a group of investors led by private equity firm Cerberus and then merged with Albertsons in a $9.4 billion deal. There is already talk of the food retailers going public again in 2015. The combined entity will have more clout with suppliers, something that could help it with the grocery industry’s notoriously low profit margins. More efficient operations will come in handy as the grocery sector gets more competitive, with Whole Foods Market planning a chain of lower-priced stores, Target looking to become a leader in organic food and Wal-Mart Stores vastly improving its fresh food assortment. The combined company, the 2nd U.S. supermarket operator after Kroger, has begun to shut down stores in a variety of markets like Denver and has been working to improve efficiencies at two grocery chains already seen as well run.

twitter.description: Safeway on the Fortune 500 via @FortuneMagazine

thumbnail.caption: A Safeway baker puts out fresh bagels at the store in Wheaton, Maryland.

seo.title: Safeway (SWY) Stock Price, Financials and News | Fortune 500

strengths: Dominant player on the West Coast
Well-run companies, particularly Safeway, which was a pioneer in offering organic food and updating how supermarkets look
weaknesses: The company had to sell dozens of stores in many markets to comply with anti-trust rules to get the merger done, leaving it with low market share in places like Chicago and Denver
opportunities: Safeway's leadership with smaller but more upscale stores can help both grocers compete with their aggressive rivals
More clout with suppliers and economies of scale could help the combined company's profit
threats: The companies' stores are concentrated on the West Coast, exposing to any slowdown in that part of the country
Wal-Mart, the top U.S. grocer by sales, and Target are each encroaching more and more noticeably on Safeway's territory.

list-items.description: Although nothing runs like Deere, its business is struggling. While the company continues to enjoy a diverse portfolio and a burgeoning number of employees of over 50,000, net sales and revenues decreased by about 5% with less consumers buying agriculture and turf products. Net income and earnings per share were also down for the year in 2014. As the global demand for grain increases, there will likely be a larger appetite for John Deere’s signature equipment. As a result, research and development remained steady in 2014 at $1.5 billion. The company forecast a challenging 2015 with a “significant reduction in sales and earnings” as demand for agricultural products continues to decline.

seo.title: Deere (DE) Stock Price, Financials and News | Fortune 500

strengths: Construction and forestry products helped defray the issues with agricultural sales in 2014
weaknesses: Because of a lack of demand for farming equipment, sales are expected to continue declining
opportunities: Rising population and an increased need for grain are future growth opportunities
The company has a diverse portfolio of products and can continue to rely on a wide range of revenue sources
threats: While Deere struggles with sales thanks to farming equipment not selling as well as in the past, it'll need to find a solution so that sales don't continue declining sharply in the years ahead

list-items.description: CEO Ellen Kullman has been a target of criticism in the past year by billionaire activist investor Nelson Peltz, who claims the company has a bloated cost structure and could be more profitable if it were broken up. This despite being a healthy investment for DuPont’s shareholders, who have seen gains of 266% over the past six years. In May, Kullman fended off a public fight and attempt by Peltz to grab four board seats by waging an unsuccessful proxy fight. Kullman posits that DuPont will be more a stronger, more profitable company as a diversified conglomerate. The company is currently going through a spinoff of its chemical performance business as they attempt to show growth once again after earnings that been flat over the last few years.

list-items.description: American Express has struggled lately. Sales were up a meager 4% last year, about half of the company’s goal. This year could likely be disappointing as well. In March, AmEx announced that it lost its long exclusive deal with retailer Costco, which accounted for 10% of AmEx’s cardholders, and about 20% of its loans. Ken Chenault is trying to replace the lost Costco users and expand the company beyond its traditionally affluent and corporate customer base. AmEx has been offering prepaid debt cards, which often appeal to people who don’t have access to a traditional bank account. AmEx is also striking up relationships with McDonald’s and Wal-mart in order to reach more everyday spending.

strengths: America Express is the dominant provider of corporate charge cards.
Tends to benefit from increases in consumer spending and travel.
weaknesses: American Express charges retailers a higher rate when consumers use their cards.
Has had trouble expanding out of the charge card space and into credit cards and lending.
opportunities: American Express is trying to expand out of its affluent niche by offering prepaid credit cards, and striking up partnerships with McDonald's and Walmart.
threats: Other card companies are beefing up their rewards programs in order to better compete with American Express for affluent customers.
Despite few ties to the financial crisis, American Express like other big banks now has to pass the Fed's annual stress test.

list-items.description: Cigna, a provider health and life insurance plans in more than 30 countries, is off to a strong start in 2015. After the first quarter, the company raised its earnings outlook as it added more customers to its health insurance plans. Like other health insurers, Cigna is gaining more individual customers as a result of the Affordable Care Act. The Bloomfield, Conn.-based insurer has also benefited from higher premiums and fees, gaining 12.3% over the first three months this year. Cigna teamed up with Catamaran in 2013 to manage its drug benefits and has recently been reaping the benefits. The deal has already boosted earnings per share by 50 cents last year and another 10 cents to 15 cents gain is expected in 2015. Cigna also has a strong cash pile on-hand, which means it could pursue strategic acquisitions to bulk up its Medicare Advantage or Medicaid units.

facebook.title: Mondelez International
facebook.description: Irene Rosenfeld has some clear messages for women who want to get ahead in business: “make a difference” and “ask for what you want.” That’s what has guided Mondelez International’s CEO, one of the few female CEOs of a Fortune 500 company. She is also ranked on Fortune’s list of the 50 Most Powerful Women […]

twitter.description: Mondelez International on the Fortune 500 via @FortuneMagazine

thumbnail.caption: Boxes of Nabisco's Oreo Cookies in multiple yummy flavors on a supermarket shelf in New York.

seo.title: Mondelez International (MDLZ) Stock Price, Financials and News | Fortune 500

strengths: The food maker has nine brands that generate a billion or more each year, including Nabisco and Oreo, and a further 58 that each generate $100 million or more.
The company sells foods in a wide variety of snacking categories, including gum & candy, cookies, chocolate and beverages.
weaknesses: Mondelez still heavily relies on mature markets for a bulk of the company's revenue: more than 60% from North America and mature markets in Europe.
It also generates a lot of money outside of North America, so it is highly exposed to swings in currency.
opportunities: The social media and online marketing environment has changed radically. If Mondelez can outperform its competitors, it could be a real advantage.
Mondelez is highly focused on marketing investments, and that's a real opportunity for the snacks maker.
threats: Snack food consumption is highly correlated to gross domestic product growth and higher incomes, especially for a growing middle class in emerging markets.
A near term threat is lower GDP growth and high unemployment in Europe and emerging markets, trends that have slowed growth in the past.

list-items.description:
In a bit to claim more than 20 million cable television subscribers, AT&T acquired DirecTV during the middle of 2014. The company’s large subscriber base and high quality offerings mean that it’s new parent company will expand its offerings tremendously. There’s also the opportunity to expand in Latin America, the company said in its 2014 annual report. The company has seen net income dip in recent years, however, while competition with DISH has increased. Being under the umbrella of a company as large as AT&T should help. But companies like Netflix have also become increasingly vocal against the provider. The online streaming service asked the Federal Communications Commission in 2015 to reject the merger. The company also saw sales increase by nearly 5%.

*Acquired by AT&T (2014 Rank: 12), July 24, 2015.

list-items.description: Halliburton managed to crack the Fortune 100, thanks to a nearly 12% bump in annual revenue, in spite of plummeting crude prices in 2014 that crushed many of the company’s oil industry clients. However, it appears the energy industry’s oil woes just took a little bit longer to catch up to Halliburton, the world’s second-largest oilfield services company, as 2015 kicked off with a steep drop in revenue and mounting losses due to declines in drilling activity. Meanwhile, Halliburton hopes to counter the effects of the drilling dearth by getting bigger through its $34.6 billion acquisition of smaller rival Baker Hughes.

twitter.description: Halliburton on the Fortune 500 via @FortuneMagazine

thumbnail.caption: Workers walk towards Halliburton Co. "sand castles" at an Anadarko Petroleum Corp. hydraulic fracturing site north of Dacono, Colorado.
thumbnail.credit: Photograph by Jamie Schwaberow — Getty Images

seo.title: Halliburton (HAL) Stock Price, Financials and News | Fortune 500

strengths: Halliburton's strong international presence means it can take advantage of slightly more favorable market conditions overseas, where drilling activity has not slowed as much as in the U.S.
The Baker Hughes purchase would put Halliburton in a better position to compete with oilfield services leader Schlumberger.
weaknesses: Losses should continue to mount with industry's reduced drilling.
Halliburton said it would lay off 8% of its workforce, or 6,400 jobs, to reduce costs.
opportunities: Getting antitrust approval for the Baker Hughes deal will require a massive asset sale that could net $10 billion.
A bigger Halliburton can expect to control a larger swath of the market once oil industry clients begin to ramp up drilling once again.
threats: The global oil glut means Halliburton's clients are cutting production and costs.
The Baker Hughes deal still awaits regulatory approval before it can officially close late in 2015.

Hits like X-Men: Days of Future Past and Rio 2 helped give the company a strong end to its most recent fiscal year, with revenues increasing 15% over the prior year, to $31.87 billion. Fox’s $80 billion bid to purchase Time Warner, however, did not go over so well. After the latter’s board rejected the offer, Murdoch decided to walk away last August.

list-items.description: The industrial-products maker, which makes Post-Its and Scotch Tape, last year reported higher sales for all business segments it serves and across almost all geographies, with Latin America/Canada the lone laggard. Though a lot of 3M’s brands are well known, the company also invests heavily in research and development, which it believes is a major driver of sales and profit growth. R&D expenses totaled $1.77 billion last year.

twitter.description: 3M on the Fortune 500 via @FortuneMagazine

thumbnail.caption: 3M Co. Post-it brand notes hang on display for sale at a supermarket in Princeton, Illinois.
thumbnail.credit: Photograph by Daniel Acker — Getty Images

seo.title: 3M (MMM) Stock Price, Financials and News | Fortune 500

strengths: Diversity is a great advantage for 3M, which sells simple Scotch masking tape and Post-Its for the office, but also provides reflective sheets used on highway signs, sells medical tapes and wound closure products and makes wood-finishing materials and filters for furnaces and air conditioners.
weaknesses: 3M's businesses can be adversely affected by disruptions in global markets and widespread recessionary conditions.
The company derives about two-thirds of its revenue from outside of the U.S.
opportunities: Other deals include the recently acquired Ivera Medical and the sale of the company's static control business in January.
3M has been busy this year with acquisitions and divestitures. It agreed to pay $1 billion to buy Polypore's filtrations business for the life sciences, industrial and specialty segments.
threats: Because most of 3M's revenue comes from outside the U.S., when the dollar is strong, it can sting the company's sales and bottom line results.
Rival products can come into the market and attempt to undercut 3M's pricing power, which could result in it slashing prices to stay competitive.

list-items.description: The struggling retailer has spent much of the last year selling off valuable assets like Lands’ End and its stake in Sears Canada, along with many of its best stores. To many this looks like a firesale, but Sears says this will give it the financial wherewithal to speed up its transformation into a more tech-driven retailer. Still its retail business continues to deteriorate quickly—Sears Holdings, which also owns Kmart, has lost a total of $7 billion in the last four years, hurt by stores that look out of date and bland merchandise. But the retailer does have a few tricks up its sleeve. Sears and Kmart were early to understand how tech will transform retail, and the retailer has an innovative loyalty program called Shop Your Way that generates a bigger share of sales every year. But Sears, and its hedge fund titan CEO, Eddie Lampert, are in a race against time, trying to modernizing the retailer even as sales crater.

weaknesses: Poorly maintained and staffed stores
Uninspiring, uninspired merchandise

Strong e-commerce backbone gives Sears the chance to offer a wide array of goods and take on Amazon
threats: Walmart and Target are upping their game, with better apparel and home goods offerings, making a Kmart comeback much harder
Sears is an anchor at a very high number of dying malls, threatening to worsen poor traffic trends

list-items.description: Combat corporation General Dynamics is the world’s third largest defense contractor after Lockheed Martin and Boeing. With products spanning land, sea, air, and cyber, the West Falls Church, Va.-based company has come a long way from its roots as a submarine manufacturer in the late 19th century. Strong demand for its Gulfstream corporate jets as well as cybersecurity services have kept the company buoyant and consistently outperformed expectations in 2014.
